title: Ecosystem
description:
A community of organisms interacting with their environment
Example: Rainforest

title: Food Chain
description:
A linear sequence of who eats whom
Example: Grassland Chain

title: Food Web
description:
A complex network of interconnected food chains
Example: Ocean Food Web

title: Trophic Level
description:
A rank in the feeding hierarchy of an ecosystem
Example: Herbivore Level

title: Primary Producer
description:
Organisms that produce their own food via photosynthesis
Example: Plants

title: Primary Consumer
description:
Organisms that consume producers
Example: Rabbits

title: Secondary Consumer
description:
Organisms that eat primary consumers
Example: Foxes

title: Tertiary Consumer
description:
Top-level predators in a food chain
Example: Hawks

title: Decomposer
description:
Organisms that break down dead matter
Example: Fungi

title: Detritivore
description:
Organisms that feed on decomposing organic material
Example: Earthworms

title: Autotroph
description:
Organisms that synthesize their own food
Example: Algae

title: Heterotroph
description:
Organisms that rely on consuming other organisms
Example: Lions

title: Omnivore
description:
Animals that eat both plants and animals
Example: Bears

title: Carnivore
description:
Animals that primarily eat other animals
Example: Tigers

title: Herbivore
description:
Animals that consume only plant matter
Example: Cows

title: Keystone Species
description:
A species that has a disproportionately large effect on its ecosystem
Example: Sea Otters

title: Apex Predator
description:
The top predator in an ecosystem
Example: Orcas

title: Biomass
description:
Total mass of living organisms in a given area
Example: Forest Biomass

title: Ecological Pyramid
description:
A graphical representation of biomass, energy, or number of organisms
Example: Energy Pyramid

title: Energy Flow
description:
The transfer of energy through different organisms
Example: Sunlight to Plants

title: Carbon Cycle
description:
The cycling of carbon through ecosystems
Example: Carbon Fixation

title: Nitrogen Cycle
description:
The movement of nitrogen through the environment
Example: Nitrogen Fixation

title: Water Cycle
description:
The continuous movement of water on Earth
Example: Evaporation

title: Photosynthesis
description:
The process by which plants convert light into energy
Example: Chlorophyll

title: Respiration
description:
The process of breaking down food for energy
Example: Cellular Respiration

title: Ecological Niche
description:
The specific role a species plays in an ecosystem
Example: Wolves in Yellowstone

title: Habitat
description:
The natural environment where an organism lives
Example: Coral Reef

title: Biome
description:
A large-scale ecological region with similar climate and life forms
Example: Tundra

title: Eutrophication
description:
Excess nutrients in water leading to algal blooms
Example: Algal Bloom

title: Biodiversity
description:
The variety of life in an ecosystem
Example: Amazon Rainforest

title: Population
description:
A group of individuals of the same species in an area
Example: Wolf Pack

title: Community
description:
Different populations interacting in an ecosystem
Example: Savanna Wildlife

title: Carrying Capacity
description:
The maximum population size an environment can support
Example: Deer Population

title: Ecological Succession
description:
The gradual process of change in an ecosystem
Example: Forest Regrowth

title: Primary Succession
description:
Succession occurring in an area with no previous life
Example: Volcanic Island

title: Secondary Succession
description:
Succession occurring where life previously existed
Example: Post-Wildfire Growth

title: Pioneer Species
description:
First species to colonize a disturbed area
Example: Lichen

title: Climax Community
description:
The final, stable stage of ecological succession
Example: Old-Growth Forest

title: Symbiosis
description:
A long-term biological interaction between species
Example: Clownfish & Anemone

title: Mutualism
description:
A relationship where both species benefit
Example: Bees & Flowers

title: Commensalism
description:
A relationship where one benefits and the other is unaffected
Example: Barnacles & Whales

title: Parasitism
description:
A relationship where one species benefits at anotherâ€™s expense
Example: Tapeworms

title: Predation
description:
One organism hunting and consuming another
Example: Lions & Zebras

title: Competition
description:
When organisms compete for the same resource
Example: Hyenas & Lions

title: Intraspecific Competition
description:
Competition within a species
Example: Male Deer Fighting

title: Interspecific Competition
description:
Competition between different species
Example: Lions vs Hyenas

title: Population Density
description:
The number of individuals per unit area
Example: City Bird Count

title: Population Growth
description:
The change in population size over time
Example: Human Population Growth

title: Birth Rate
description:
The number of births per unit time
Example: Birth Rate in Elephants

title: Death Rate
description:
The number of deaths per unit time
Example: Mortality in Deer

title: Migration
description:
Movement of individuals into or out of a population
Example: Bird Migration

title: Dispersion
description:
The pattern of spacing among individuals
Example: Schooling Fish

title: R-Selected Species
description:
Species that reproduce quickly and have many offspring
Example: Mice

title: K-Selected Species
description:
Species that invest heavily in fewer offspring
Example: Elephants

title: Metapopulation
description:
A group of populations separated but connected by migration
Example: Tiger Reserves

title: Species Richness
description:
The number of different species in an area
Example: Coral Reef Fish

title: Species Evenness
description:
How evenly individuals are distributed among species
Example: Equal Bird Species

title: Dominant Species
description:
A species that has the greatest impact on an ecosystem
Example: Oak Trees

title: Indicator Species
description:
A species that signals environmental health
Example: Frogs

title: Edge Effect
description:
Changes that occur at habitat boundaries
Example: Forest Edge

title: Conservation Biology
description:
The study of preserving biodiversity
Example: Endangered Species Act

title: Wildlife Management
description:
The practice of managing wildlife populations
Example: National Parks

title: Endangered Species
description:
A species at risk of extinction
Example: Pandas

title: Extinct Species
description:
A species that no longer exists
Example: Dodo

title: Habitat Fragmentation
description:
The breaking up of habitats into smaller patches
Example: Road Construction

title: Protected Area
description:
A designated area for protecting ecosystems
Example: Amazon Reserve

title: Biodiversity Hotspot
description:
An area with exceptionally high biodiversity
Example: Madagascar

title: Wildlife Corridor
description:
A natural passageway for wildlife movement
Example: Animal Crossings

title: Captive Breeding
description:
Breeding endangered species in captivity
Example: Zoo Breeding Programs

title: Rewilding
description:
Restoring species to their natural habitat
Example: Bison Reintroduction

title: Invasive Species
description:
Non-native species that harm ecosystems
Example: Kudzu Plant

title: Ecological Restoration
description:
The process of restoring ecosystems
Example: Wetland Restoration

title: Deforestation
description:
The clearing of forests
Example: Amazon Deforestation

title: Desertification
description:
The process of land becoming desert
Example: Sahara Expansion

title: Climate Change
description:
Long-term shifts in climate patterns
Example: Rising Temperatures

title: Overexploitation
description:
The excessive use of natural resources
Example: Overfishing

title: Poaching
description:
Illegal hunting of protected species
Example: Ivory Trade

title: Sustainable Development
description:
Development that meets present and future needs
Example: Solar Energy

title: Ecotourism
description:
Tourism that supports conservation efforts
Example: Whale Watching

title: Carbon Sequestration
description:
The process of capturing and storing atmospheric carbon
Example: Tree Planting

title: Biotic Factors
description:
Living components of an ecosystem
Example: Trees & Animals

title: Abiotic Factors
description:
Non-living environmental factors
Example: Sunlight & Soil

title: Ecotone
description:
A transition zone between ecosystems
Example: Mangrove Forest Edge

title: Microhabitat
description:
A small, specialized habitat
Example: Leaf Litter

title: Macrohabitat
description:
A large-scale habitat
Example: Amazon Rainforest

title: Ecological Efficiency
description:
The efficiency of energy transfer in a food web
Example: Energy Transfer

title: Trophic Cascade
description:
The effect predators have on lower trophic levels
Example: Wolves Affecting Elk

title: Decomposition
description:
The breakdown of organic material
Example: Fungi Breaking Down Leaves

title: Biogeochemical Cycles
description:
Natural cycles of nutrients
Example: Nitrogen Cycle

title: Primary Productivity
description:
The rate of biomass production by autotrophs
Example: Forest Growth

title: Secondary Productivity
description:
The energy available to herbivores
Example: Crop Growth

title: Ecological Footprint
description:
The impact of human activity on nature
Example: Per Capita Land Use

title: Limiting Factor
description:
A factor that limits population growth
Example: Water Availability

title: Homeostasis
description:
The ability of an ecosystem to maintain stability
Example: Stable Coral Reefs

title: Ecological Equilibrium
description:
A balanced state of an ecosystem
Example: Balanced Food Webs

title: Photosynthetic Efficiency
description:
The efficiency of converting sunlight into energy
Example: Efficient Algae Growth

title: Gross Primary Productivity
description:
Total energy captured by producers
Example: Photosynthetic Plants

title: Net Primary Productivity
description:
Energy remaining after respiration
Example: Forests Storing Carbon

title: Ecological Indicator
description:
Species that indicate environmental health
Example: Amphibians

title: Biomagnification
description:
The accumulation of toxins in food chains
Example: Mercury in Tuna

title: Population Ecology
description:
The study of population dynamics
Example: Deer Populations

title: Demography
description:
Statistical study of populations
Example: Human Census

title: Age Structure
description:
Distribution of ages in a population
Example: Elephant Herd Age Groups

title: Survivorship Curve
description:
Graph showing lifespan trends
Example: Human Lifespan Trends

title: Carrying Capacity Overshoot
description:
When populations exceed sustainable levels
Example: Locust Swarms

title: Density-Dependent Factor
description:
Factors dependent on population size
Example: Predation Effects

title: Density-Independent Factor
description:
Factors independent of population size
Example: Weather Events

title: Fecundity
description:
Reproductive potential
Example: Rabbit Reproduction

title: Allee Effect
description:
Low population densities reduce survival
Example: Lack of Mates in Small Groups

title: Boom-and-Bust Cycle
description:
Rapid growth followed by collapse
Example: Booming Rodents

title: Species Interactions
description:
Interactions between species
Example: Predator-Prey Dynamics

title: Guild
description:
A group of species exploiting the same resources
Example: Desert Carnivores

title: Trophic Guild
description:
A group feeding at the same trophic level
Example: Grazing Mammals

title: Ecological Network
description:
A web of species interactions
Example: Interconnected Forest Species

title: Dominance Hierarchy
description:
A ranking system within species
Example: Wolf Pack Hierarchy

title: Social Carrying Capacity
description:
The limit of human-wildlife interaction
Example: Park Visitor Limits

title: Ecological Drift
description:
Random changes in community composition
Example: Random Species Changes

title: Keystone Mutualist
description:
Mutualists critical for ecosystem function
Example: Bees & Flowers

title: Functional Diversity
description:
The range of different species functions
Example: Pollinators in Rainforests

title: Niche Partitioning
description:
Species dividing resources to reduce competition
Example: Bird Feeding Differences

title: Biodiversity Conservation
description:
The protection of biodiversity
Example: Tiger Protection

title: Ex-Situ Conservation
description:
Conservation outside natural habitats
Example: Zoos

title: In-Situ Conservation
description:
Conservation within natural habitats
Example: National Parks

title: Wildlife Reserve
description:
An area set aside for wildlife protection
Example: Savanna Reserves

title: Biosphere Reserve
description:
A protected region balancing conservation and development
Example: Amazon Biosphere

title: Ramsar Sites
description:
Wetlands of international importance
Example: Wetlands Protection

title: CITES
description:
A treaty protecting endangered species
Example: Wildlife Trade Ban

title: Endemic Species
description:
Species found only in one location
Example: Kangaroos

title: Red List
description:
A global conservation status list
Example: IUCN Status

title: Ecological Resilience
description:
An ecosystemâ€™s ability to recover from disturbances
Example: Coral Reef Recovery

title: Habitat Degradation
description:
Decline in habitat quality
Example: Logging Impact

title: Reforestation
description:
Restoring deforested areas
Example: Amazon Reforestation

title: Afforestation
description:
Planting trees in barren areas
Example: Tree Plantation

title: Carbon Footprint
description:
The total carbon emissions of an individual or group
Example: Carbon Reduction Plans

title: Greenhouse Effect
description:
The trapping of heat by atmospheric gases
Example: Rising Global Temperatures

title: Plastic Pollution
description:
Harm caused by plastic waste
Example: Plastic Waste in Oceans

title: Ocean Acidification
description:
The decrease in ocean pH due to COâ‚‚ absorption
Example: Coral Bleaching

title: Trophic Downgrading
description:
The loss of top predators affecting ecosystems
Example: Shark Population Decline

title: Fragmentation Edge Effects
description:
Changes in ecosystems due to habitat fragmentation
Example: Roadside Forest Strips

title: Corridor Ecology
description:
The study of wildlife corridors
Example: Jungle Bridges

title: Anthropogenic Impact
description:
Human activities affecting nature
Example: Deforestation

title: Climate Mitigation
description:
Reducing human impact on climate
Example: Wind & Solar Energy

title: Climate Adaptation
description:
Adjusting to climate changes
Example: Flood Barriers

title: Carbon Neutrality
description:
Balancing carbon emissions with absorption
Example: Carbon Offsetting

title: Sustainable Agriculture
description:
Farming that preserves ecosystems
Example: Permaculture

title: Ecosystem Services
description:
Benefits provided by ecosystems
Example: Pollination Services

title: Ecological Economics
description:
Economic valuation of nature
Example: Environmental Economics

title: Overfishing
description:
The depletion of fish stocks
Example: Shark Overfishing

title: Desert Greening
description:
Reversing desertification
Example: African Reforestation

title: Urban Ecology
description:
Study of ecology in cities
Example: Urban Green Spaces
